com.communote.server.core.vo.content

Class AttachmentTO

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.communote.server.core.vo.AbstractTransferObject
      • com.communote.server.core.vo.content.AttachmentTO
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AttachmentFileTO, AttachmentRedirectTO, AttachmentStreamTO

    public abstract class AttachmentTO
extends AbstractTransferObject
implements Serializable
    The AttachmentTO encapsulates the logic to access an attachment by streams. The streams source can be either a file or a stream which is defined by the subclasses. The encapsulation is necessary to assure the closing of the input streams as they got accessed. Use the write methods to write an attachment either to a file or to another stream.
    Author:
    Communote GmbH - http://www.communote.com/
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getContentLength

        public long getContentLength()
        Get the content length. That will be length of the meta data, if set, or the length that could be predetermined (e.g. if the source is a file). However after the write method has been called the length is updated (also in the meta data, if not null).
        Returns:
        the content length

      • setNoteId

        public void setNoteId(Long noteId)
        NoteId is ignored on creating a note and associating it. Use create note of NoteManagement to connect attachments with notes.
        Parameters:
        noteId - id of the note the attachment is associated with. null if no note connected.

      • write

        public void write(File file)
           throws IOException
        Open the stream and write its content to the file. After writing the stream will be closed and the number of written bytes will be stored in the content length member of the metadata ( #metadata#setContentLength(long)) if metadata is not null.
        Parameters:
        file - the file to write to
        Throws:
        IOException - in case of an error

      • write

        public void write(File file,
                  long maxLength)
           throws IOException
        Open the stream and write at most maxLength bytes of the content to the file. After writing the stream will be closed and the number of written bytes will be stored in the content length member of the metadata ( #metadata#setContentLength(long)) if metadata is not null.
        Parameters:
        file - the file to write to
        maxLength - See IOHelper.write(InputStream, OutputStream, long) for more information.
        Throws:
        IOException - in case of an error

      • write

        public void write(OutputStream outStream)
           throws IOException
        Write the attachment to the output stream. Will not close the output stream.
        Parameters:
        outStream - the output stream
        Throws:
        IOException - in case of an error

      • write

        public void write(OutputStream outStream,
                  long maxLength)
           throws IOException
        Write the attachment to the output stream. Will not close the output stream.
        Parameters:
        outStream - the output stream
        maxLength - See IOHelper.write(InputStream, OutputStream, long) for more information.
        Throws:
        IOException - in case of an error
